noun.definition: (military) a form signed by a soldier to declare that they are homosexual. Pronounced "three-oh-two".
noun.example:
- Eh, hear say Rayner got sign 302.
- Huh issit? He not like very gu niang one leh.

noun.definition: (military) a form signed in the SAF by a soldier who has lost or caused damage to SAF equipment, acknowledging a deduction in their pay. Pronounced twelve-oh-six.
noun.example: Jialat... my chocolate bar fell off? Later go back must sign 1206 ah?

noun.definition: (military) a form for documenting the receipt and issuance of goods.

abuden.usage: Tone / rhythm of dictation may convey slightly different emotions; abuden? said quickly is typically passive-aggressive or dismissive, whereas ah-bu-den? can indicate annoyance or exasperation.

interjection.definition: if not, what?
duh

abuden.etyNotes: Development of this phrase was likely also influenced by English 'ah, but then?' - see @{ah then}.

verb.definition: To feign ignorance; to play dumb
verb.example: Alamak, you next time really must act blur ba.

interjection.definition: oh my god, oh dear
interjection.example: “Aiyo! Nearly langgar leh! So scary ah! Alamak! Why you go so fast!” he is heard exclaiming to a companion in his car.
interjection.exampleSource: 2019, Cherlynn Ng, “Near-collision with Mercedes going against traffic during rain in Yishun: 'So scary ah!'”, in AsiaOne

adjective.example: You think you are going for a vacation izzit? No wonder our athletes thought like this and we lost miserably. So lau kui.

verb.definition: to lose face; to disgrace oneself

lau khui.usage: More commonly an adjective in Singlish, but both uses are valid.

verb.definition: to embarrass; to disgrace
verb.example: In other words, I think what Mr Ha means is that Xiaxue had “sia suay” their industry.
verb.exampleSource: 2015 March 23, S M Ong, “Xiaxue not so 'sia suay' after all?”, in The New Paper, Singapore, archived from the original on 25 March 2015

adjective.definition: causing embarrassment or disgrace to others.
adjective.example: Most of those who sing these songs are too drunk to be stopped. Sia suay only.
adjective.exampleSource: 1989 November 2, “From love songs to 'pai kia' tune. Karaoke is BIG business.”, in The Straits Times

interjection.definition: my goodness; oh my god; holy crap

sia.usage: Sial and siol are used more by the Malay community. The form sia is used most commonly as a particle, and seldom as an interjection.

particle.definition: Used at the end of a clause as an intensifier; adds a degree of coarseness.
particle.example: Aiseh! This stall the chilli power sia!

interjection.definition: (vulgar) damn; bastard

particles.example: Eh sial lah! What I do I just came...

verb.definition: bluff; lie; pretend

adjective.example: Eh this pic I go Japan take one, sui anot?
He knows that whatever you do, you have to cho sui-sui.
adjective.exampleSource: 2005 Richard Lim The Straits Times (Life!) (from Straits Times Interactive), 20 August

verb.definition: (vulgar) fuck
(vulgar) scold

interjection.definition: (vulgar) fuck!
I'm/we're screwed

particles.example: My blank attachment where sia?? Hong kan liao!

limbu.usage: Female speaker. Female equivalent of limpeh.

pronoun.example: Lim bu ka li kong, you better listen.

limpeh.usage: Male speaker. Male equivalent of limbu.

pronoun.example: 恁爸是我; 我是恁爸！(Limpeh is me; I am Limpeh!)
pronoun.exampleSource: ShiGGa Shay - "LimPeh". LimPeh - EP, Ginette Chittick, 2014.

lin lao peh.usage: Male speaker. Male equivalent of lin lao bu.

lin lao bu.usage:
Female speaker. Female equivalent of lin lao peh.
May be considered vulgar or taken as a severe insult, due to its use as the interjection.

interjection.definition: (vulgar) your mother

noun.definition: A bite-sized snack consisting of a thin, crispy fried tart shell with a filling of shredded jicama (bangkuang) and other small shredded or diced ingredients, including black fungus, carrots, hard-boiled eggs, and prawns. It is commonly topped with kicap manis and chilli sauce. Believed to have derived as a snack-sized version of popiah. Origin: Peranakan.

chio.usage: Used to be considered slightly vulgar, due to conflation with Hokkien 𪁎 chhio (in heat; horny) - see chiobu. However, in modern usage it is almost always used as a compliment without a negative or vulgar connotation.

adjective.example:
- That girl in lecture yesterday sibeh chio right, you think got chance?
- Wait long long bro...

noun.definition: a handsome young man
noun.example: Everyone in the room couldn't help but notice the new intern, who was not only skilled at his job but also quite the 'yandao'.

noun.definition: handsome boy; good-looking fellow
noun.example: Many people were drawn to him, not just for his talent, but also for his reputation as a 'leng zai' in the industry.

noun.definition: term of address for a young gentleman
noun.example: Even hardened gangsters teasingly addressed him as leng zai or 'pretty boy' and told him to marry their daughters so they would have grandchildren as cute as he was.
noun.exampleSource: 2019 June 27, Ovidia Yu, The Paper Bark Tree Mystery, Constable

adjective.example: And whenever he visited he'd bring food from the kopitiam next door, and Mrs Wong would laugh and say aiyoh, leng zai, so sweet. […]He could see her mother's mouth widen with laughter as she called him leng zai, could just about picture the colour on her painted nails as she passed around the lo mai gai he'd bought for the other aunties to eat.
adjective.exampleSource: 2021, Daryl Qilin Yam, Lovelier, Lonelier, Epigram Books

noun.definition: a handsome man
term of address for a young gentleman
noun.example: Despite his modesty, his friends always teased him by calling him 'hamsum' due to his striking features.

adverb.definition: in any way or manner whatsoever; in a random fashion
adverb.example: You don't go anyhow say people hor.

particles.meaning: describing something done in an anyhow manner
anything is fine; whichever way you like
particles.example: - You want which drink? I go order.</br>- Anyhow ba, I thirsty already.

whack.usage: When whack is used in the second sense, it is almost always in the phrases "anyhow whack" or "just whack".

origin.lit: (lit.) hit; (generally) do or perform an action; used to verbify a noun

verb.definition: attack; beat up
verb.example: The driver drew out his toolbox and handed me a long spanner. ‘Eh signaller, for you to whack the pai nang.’ ‘Thanks, but if I kena whack, I’ll still rely on your Shaolin wushu to help me.’
verb.exampleSource: 1994 C.S. Chong NS: An Air-Level Story p.90

verb.definition: tackle a task without necessarily having the requisite knowledge or skills to do so
verb.example: If you’ve ever walked past a Singapore Pools outlet and found yourself itching for a bet and prepared to “just whack” on any match...

verb.definition: do (especially eat) hurriedly or greedily; wallop
verb.example: When the restaurant first came up with its all-you-can-eat promo, hundreds of Singaporean office workers descended upon it at lunchtime to try their luck at whacking the promising buffet.

whack.etyNotes: Likely a calque from Hokkien 拍 phah, which carries both the literal meaning "hit; beat; strike; whack", as well as the general sense of "to do an action", and is sometimes used to verbify a noun.

anyhow whack.usage: When whack is used in this sense, it is almost always in the phrases "anyhow whack" or "just whack".

origin.lit: do without necessarily having the requisite knowledge or skills
etyLit: (lit.) hit; (generally) do or perform an action; used to verbify a noun

verb.definition: tackle a task spontaneously and unsystematically, without necessarily having the requisite knowledge or skills to do so
verb.example: Instead of following the recipe, she decided to just anyhow whack and see what happened.

aiyoh.usage: Exact meaning depends heavily on tone and context.
aiyoh.etyNotes: Common expression in many Dravidian languages; possibly borrowed into Chinese languages from Tamil ஐயோ aiyō. See aiyoyo (Tamil ஐயையோ, aiyaiyō).

interjection.definition: oh dear; oh no; ouch; alas; exclamation of distress, pain, admiration, etc.
interjection.example: Aiyo, I forgot to bring my umbrella, and now it's gonna rain!

aiyoyo.usage: Used as a more intense version of aiyoh.
aiyoyo.etyNotes: While its origin is in Dravidian languages such as Tamil, the word was likely also proliferated through Chinese languages as a semi-reduplication of 哎哟 āiyō → 哎哟哟 āiyōyō.

interjection.definition: oh dear; oh no; ouch; alas; exclamation of grief, distress, pain, pity, etc.
interjection.example: Aiyoyo, cannot lah! Like that later sure kena scolding.

adjective.example: Ah Soon damn steady one, never siam work never keng never take MC.

interjection.definition: alright!; nice!

adjective.definition: (of two people) in an exclusive and long-term relationship
adjective.example: I didn't realise you and Ah Lian were steady; congrats!

adverb.definition: (with 'go') to begin an exclusive and committed relationship
adverb.example: Rani and Ah Hee had gone steady eight months ago, unbeknownst to their heavily disapproving parents.

stead.usage: See @{steady}. May be used as a short form of @{kia stead} in many cases.

verb.definition: begin an exclusive and committed relationship; go steady
begin an exclusive and committed relationship; go steady
verb.example: After paktoring for several months, they decided to kia stead and commit to a more serious relationship.

origin.lit: (interrogative) (do you) want or not want (sth.)?; 愛 (want) + contraction of 毋愛 (not want)

interrogative.definition: (dating) do you want to go steady (or not)?
interrogative.example:
- Bee ah, ai stead mai?
- Hehe ons!

pak tor.usage: Usually jocular, teasing, or endearing, and intended to elicit sheepishness or bashfulness amongst one or both of the dating parties.
pak tor.etyNotes: The term originally means "hitched together" in Cantonese, referring to the common sight of cargo-carrying motorboats tied to and dragging smaller row-boats in the Pearl River Delta region (the area of Guangdong/Hong Kong/Macau). As an analogy for dating, the word had also made its way into other languages throughout history (such as Hokkien, Teochew, and Hakka), where it is now also a commonly used term.

origin.lit: date; go out on a date with sb.

verb.definition: go out on a romantic date with somebody
verb.example: He adds that he goes there with his children once every two months. "A lot of memories. First time I paktor (dated) with my wife was there."
verb.exampleSource: 1994 November 20, “The scattering of Satay Club”, in The Straits Times (Leisure), page 32

verb.definition: date somebody romantically
verb.example: That shares the spotlight with Lautner, who plays Cam, a bicycle courier looking to "paktor" (Cantonese slang for "court") with parkour hottie Nikki (Marie Avgeropoulos).
verb.exampleSource: 2015 February 27, “Parkour caper is purely a star vehicle for Lautner”, in The Business Times (Singapore), page 37:

verb.definition: (colloquial) be generally physical intimate with somebody

origin.lit: date; go out on a date with sb.
etyLit: date; go out on a date with sb.

origin.lit:
a branch of learning; a study;
(humorous) suffixed tongue-in-cheek to an english word to create a hypothetical subject of study

noun.definition: (humorous) the study or science of dating
noun.example: Years of research in the scientific field of 'paktohlogy' have shown that horror movies are the best to watch on a date.
noun.exampleSource: 2015 February 13, hitz.fm, "First Vday together? Then stay away from These 5 Movie types", online

steady pom pi pi.etyNotes: Pom pi pi is a semi-reduplication of 𬅫觱 pûn-pi (to whistle; also 𬅫喙觱 pûn-chhùi-pi, 𬅫觱仔 pûn pi-á) → 𬅫觱觱 pûn-pi-pi.

adjective.definition: capable; ready; solid; keeping cool under any situation. An emphasized variant of steady.
adjective.example: He's a good boss lah. We pulled through the recession because even though everywhere else is crashing, he still steady pom pi pi.
adjective.exampleSource: 2022 August 9, Delfina Utomo, Time Out Singapore. "Singlish words we don’t hear anymore". Retrieved from https://www.timeout.com/singapore/things-to-do/singlish-words-we-dont-hear-anymore

interjection.definition: steady

adjective.definition: spoilsport; describing a person whose behaviour sours situations for others
adjective.example:
- Wee Kheng every time si peh buay steady sia. I never do homework he also must go pau toh.
- Cheh, no wonder you just now tioh kan by Mdm Kuan.

origin.lit: affirmative particle; able to; permitted to

interjection.definition: why is it allowed; why is it possible; in what sense would this do or suffice; in what way is this fair
interjection.example: I tapau with my own container I still must pay the 50 cents? How can?!

adverb.definition: (interrogative) in what way will this do or suffice
adverb.example: The fella so buay steady; how can trust?

noun.definition: an alteration of zebra.

cock stand.etyNotes: May have been derived directly from the archaic English word "cockstand", sometimes rendered as "cock-stand", which had the same meaning. See 2008, Ayto, John, and Simpson, John. 'Oxford Dictionary of Modern Slang'. Oxford University Press, p.54.

verb.definition: have an erection; become erect

origin.lit: sexually excited; stimulated; have an erection

idiom.definition: describing a bustling, often incomprehensible flurry of activity; (lit) to die in the midst of such a great flurry or excitement that one retains an erection after death
idiom.example: Sergeant: "If you screw up again, I will make sure you do so many push ups that you die cockstand!"

idiom.definition: an activity or experience which is indescribably awesome or pleasurable
idiom.example: I love Bangkok! It's die cock stand!

kam lan.etyNotes: The same term exists in Cantonese as ham lan 含撚 ham4 lan2, with the same meanings. 撚 is an alternate character for 𡳞 which is used more often in Cantonese.

origin.lit: hold or keep in one's mouth

verb.definition: (vulgar) fellate
(vulgar) to screw off; go to hell
(vulgar) be condemned; be screwed

pengsan.usage: Frequently jocular; often used in the context of having to do hard work, or having a long or tough day.

verb.definition: faint; lose consciousness
verb.example: When he heard the news, he nearly pengsan from shock.

expression.definition: don't play around; don't play a fool; be serious
expression.example: When it comes to safety rules, jangan main-main.

play play.etyNotes: Possibly also influenced as a calque from Chinese languages.

verb.definition: mess around; play a fool; be unserious

origin.lit: mess around; play a fool; be unserious

expression.definition: don't play around; don't play a fool; be serious. Popularized by the titular character Phua Chu Kang, played by local actor Gurmit Singh.

auntie.usage: May be considered rude or impolite if used on a young woman, or one around the same age as oneself.
auntie.etyNotes: Calling older women "auntie" (or some term meaning "auntie" in the native language) as a form of polite address is and has been prevalent throughout cultures in Asia, Africa, and many other places elsewhere in the world; the Singlish use is a continuation of this phenomenon.

origin.lit: diminutive of aunt (female relative of the same generation as one's parent)
etyLit: equivalent of "auntie" in various languages and cultures; woman of older generation than oneself

noun.definition: a respectful term of address for a woman of an older generation than the speaker, regardless of relation.
noun.example: Auntie, want to sit?

adjective.definition: a young person whose mannerisms, habits, behaviour, and/or fashion style are outmoded or resemble those of women from a much older generation.
adjective.example: Alicia damn auntie one; every time I see her bring the $2 tissue packet to wipe table.

thank yout.usage: This variant usually only appears when used as a standalone interjection, rather than as a verb or as beginning a longer clause; i.e. "Thank yout." vs. "Thank you for the..."

interjection.definition: "thank you", with the final syllable having been altered to end in a glottal stop. Possibly to assert a sense of finality, curtness, or confirmation; may have been influenced by the prevalence of syllables ending in glottal stops in Hokkien and other Min Nan languages.

pasar.etyNotes: Also made its way through Malay into Standard Singaporean Mandarin and other Chinese languages as 巴刹 (Mandarin: bāshā, Hokkien: pa-sat, Cantonese: baa1 saat3, Teochew: ba1 sag4, etc.) The variant spelling pasat is from the Hokkien pronunciation (seen in names like Lau Pa Sat).

noun.definition: market
night market
noun.example:
- Bro tomorrow night want to go pasar malam buy Ramly?
- Cannot, I so gemuk oredi la...

origin.lit: hey!; interjection for address expressing disrespect or intimacy

interjection.definition: used to address or attract the attention of somebody; may range from disrespectful to friendly and affectionate based on closeness and context.
interjection.example: "Dey, brother, come here!" someone called from behind me.

noun.definition:
(military, abbreviation) a soldier's official identity card, given to replace their national identity card (pink IC) when they are enlisted into the SAF.
According to the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF), it stands for the 11 basic pieces of information written on the card; namely: name, NRIC number, photo, race, blood group, birth date, country of birth, sex, service status, military rank status, and address. It may entitle the holder to discounts and promotions on occasions like SAF day.
The 11B is retained after national service is completed, but with a sticker pasted over the military status indicating that the serviceman is now an NSMan.
(military) a temporary military IC issued to a soldier who has lost their military IC (@{11B}). It has to be used alongside a valid photo ID and a police report.

a lottery game popular in Singapore, run by Singapore Pools. Believed to have originated in Kedah in 1951. Name refers to the four-digit number players choose, from 0000 to 9999, which is matched against a draw of 23 winning numbers.

5-10.etyNotes: Also may be called 五十 (wǔ shí), 五 (wǔ), 十 (shí), and other various combinations amongst Chinese language speakers.

noun.definition:
a game played by at least two people, or a larger group of any size.
Players hold up both fists, and take turns shouting out a multiple of five (0, 5, 10, 15, 20 - or higher, bounded by the number of players in play), while all players simultaneously open none, one, or both of their hands. The number corresponds to the player's guess of the number of fingers held up (hence being a multiple of five). While rules may vary, one variant is that if a player guessed correctly on their turn, they get to guess again, and if getting two correct guesses in a row, the others have to perform a forfeit.
Originated as a Chinese drinking game.

5cs.etyNotes: "C" is the initial letter of cash, car, credit card, condominium, and country club.

noun.definition: a phrase referring to the five status symbols of cash, car, credit card, condominium, and country club; historically held to be the five goals of a successful working Singaporean. Sometimes also alludes to the clout and materialistic goals many spend their lives chasing after, in order to impress others.

adjective.definition: (initialism) describing someone who is routinely solicits the attention of others through loud, showy, provocative, tactless, and unabashed means.
adjective.example: Never see she show half ball meh.. so A.A.!
adjective.exampleSource: 2005 February 27, Renee Tan, The Sunday Times, p.38

abacus beads.etyNotes:
Rendered in Mandarin as suànpánzǐ (Pinyin).
note: verification on the Hakka etymology is requested from a native/fluent Hakka speaker!

noun.definition:
a Hakka dish, made with a dough of taro and tapioca flour that is typically shaped into rounded biconcave discs and boiled, before being stir-fried with various ingredients like minced pork, mushrooms, and spring onions.
Since its namesake - the abacus - is associated with accounting, abacus beads are often taken as a symbol of wealth and prosperity.

abacus seeds.etyNotes:
Rendered in Mandarin as suànpánzǐ (Pinyin).
note: verification on the Hakka etymology is requested from a native/fluent Hakka speaker!

noun.definition: See @{abacus beads}.

origin.lit: older brother; male person older than oneself

noun.definition: term of address or endearment for a male person slightly older than oneself; big brother
noun.example: Tucked away at a tiny little coffeehouse in Ang Mo Kio, Abang Gemuk is a halal-certified Western food stall from the same people behind Fatty Bom Bom.
noun.exampleSource: 2020 April 7. Eatbook.sg, "Abang Gemuk Review: Halal Western Food With Huge Portions At Ang Mo Kio". Retrieved from https://eatbook.sg/abang-gemuk-ang-mo-kio/

noun.definition: term of address for an elder son

abit.usage: Often used meiotically to mean "very" or "noticeably" instead of " a little bit".

origin.lit: slightly; to a small extent; rather

adverb.example:
- Want get dessert? Got a very nice @{cendol} place round the corner.
- If you want you go ahead ba; I still abit @{jelak} from dinner.
Recruit, you abit the special isit? Wake up your bloody idea!

abit the.usage: Usually precedes an adjective, rather than a noun (unlike how the definite article "the" is used in English).

origin.lit: a little; (sarcastic, meiosis) quite; rather; very
etyLit: slightly; to a small extent; rather

adverb.example: You a bit the blur leh...

noun.definition: a local variation of Indian pickles (achar), usually made using a mixture of vegetables, chilli padi, shallots, lime, and sometimes other ingredients including fruits and peanuts.

expression.definition:
do not present yourself to be as capable as you really are, or pretend you are incompetent and ignorant, and you will encounter less troubles and problems, or be given less work.
Possibly originated as military slang.

act cute.usage: Can be used to express annoyance or weariness at the subject's cutesy antics.

verb.definition: to behave in an (often exaggeratedly) charming, quirky, adorable, or innocent manner.
verb.example: I can always tell when my girl needs me to do something... she always out of the blue start to act cute one.

adjective.definition: describing someone behaving in such a cutesy manner.
adjective.example: See you two liddat so act blur act cute... don't think I dunno is one of you who broke the TV hor!

origin.lit: behave in an (often exaggeratedly) charming, quirky, adorable, or innocent manner

adjective.definition: (expression) describing a person behaving in an exaggeratedly cutesy manner, which is obviously feigned or a front, and comes across as unnecessary and irritating. Can also describe the manner in which they are acting.

origin.lit:
to perform a motion;
(interjection) a command to begin sth., esp. a performance or act

adjective.definition: blustering, arrogant, and pompous in one's behaviour and bearing.
adjective.example: Wei Kiat admits that his grasp of English grammar is poor and his vocabulary, weak. He does not speak “high class English” to his friends and family. Says Wei Kiat, “Wait people think I very action.”
adjective.exampleSource: 2006 July 30, Nur Amira Abdul Karim (quoting Ang Wei Kiat). The Sunday Times, p.35

verb.definition: to boast; to show off

origin.lit:
to perform a motion;
(interjection) a command to begin sth., esp. a performance or act

verb.definition: appear to be doing something; put on a display; act like one is doing more than one is busy with
verb.example: Eh, boss coming, action action a bit! If not he will arrow you to do more @{saikang}.

adjective.definition: (of people) appearing as if they are something they are not
adjective.example: He say until his @{England} so @{powderful} liddat, but he just action only; later you hear him try spiaking English, really can @{vomit blood} sia.

akshen aje.etyNotes: Malay variant of the common Singlish construction action + only.

origin.lit: (of people) appearing as if they are something they are not
etyLit:
to perform a motion;
(interjection) a command to begin sth.,esp. a performance or act

adjective.definition: appearing to be something one is not, especially acting tough.

origin.lit: younger sibling; term of address for a younger sibling in a family

noun.definition: term of address or endearment for a person slightly younger than oneself; little sibling
term of address for a younger sibling in a family

interjection.definition: ouch!; an exclamation in response to physical pain, or sympathy to another's pain, or expressing emotional hurt as a reply to an insult.
a general exclamation of disapproval, consternation, disbelief, surprise, etc.
interjection.example: “Adoooi,” the cabbie shook his head, as he pulled out of the lane. “Nowadays, the children ah!” ... “Saturday night, adoi! My cab can be like tiger show, you know? Some of the girls wear dental floss only!”
interjection.exampleSource: 2008 December 28, Colin Goh. The Sunday Times (LifeStyle), p.11

verb.definition: to guess; to estimate
verb.example:
- You sure?
- Not really, I agak only.

noun.definition: a guess; an estimation
noun.example: [A]ll along she’d cooked by agak (estimation). So when she wrote the cookbook, she had to discipline herself to putting everything into measurements.
noun.exampleSource: 2004 May 9, Teo Pau Lin (quoting Pamelia Lee). The Straits Times (LifeStyle), p.32

agak-agak.usage: Not to be confused with @{agar-agar}, which is a type of jelly.

verb.definition: to guess; to estimate
verb.example: When cooking, for example, if asked how much sugar you put in, you could reply 'I just agak-agak.'
verb.exampleSource: 1999, Adam Brown, Singapore English in a Nutshell‎. Singapore: Federal Publications, p.3

adjective.example: Kelly always said,'We Baba follow the agak-agak principle.'
adjective.exampleSource: 2007, Sidney Cheung, Chee-Beng Tan, editors. Food and Foodways in Asia: Resource, Tradition and Cooking, Abingdon: Routledge.

verb.definition: hold back; not go too far
verb.example: Don't give the kids so much homework in one day lah. Agak tarik a bit, they've got other classes to study for as well!

agar-agar.usage: Not to be confused with @{agak-agak}, which is a term meaning to guesstimate, or describing something as approximated.

origin.lit: a jelly typically made from the gracilaria and gelidiaceae genera of red algae
etyLit: the red algae from which agar-agar jelly is produced

noun.definition: an edible jelly-like substance made from red algae, traditionally used as an ingredient in making jellied desserts.

agaration.usage: Backformations such as agarate or agarating, as well as the related agar-ing, may be seen - albeit nonstandard and almost always used humorously or ironically.
agaration.etyNotes:
The -k is altered to -r either due to the phonology flowing better, or due to misidentification of the '-ation' suffix in English as including the 'r' ('-ration'), it being present in common words such as 'migration', 'generation', and 'celebration'. This was either a common enough mistake that it became standard, or done ironically or humorously.
Similar formations are seen in terms like @{chiminology}, where @{chim} is merged with almost the whole of 'criminology' rather than just the suffix '-(o)logy'.

origin.lit: an action or process, or the result thereof
etyLit: an action or process, or the result thereof
form of the -tiō suffix added to a noun to form another noun relating to an action or the result thereof

noun.definition: a guess; an estimation
noun.example: I didn't mean that I watch exactly 10 hours of TV every week for sure; that figure was just an agaration.

noun.definition: the process or action of estimating (@{agak}).
noun.example:
- How much is that in total?
- Just do some agaration... close enough also can lah.

particle.definition: used at the end of a sentence as a question or interrogative marker; tag asking for clarification
particle.example:
This is free? I take two also can?
→ This is free ah? I take two also can ah?

particle.definition: used to emphasize a question sentence
particle.example:
Why you so liddat?
→ Why you so liddat ah?

particle.definition: used to impart a didactic or chiding tone (such as at the end of an imperative clause); may carry a tone of caution.
particle.example:
Don't play play.
→ Don't play play ah...

particle.definition: used to express that the speaker is awaiting confirmation or acknowledgement of the sentence
particle.example:
Ah boy, study hard, don't come home too late.
→ Ah boy, study hard, don't come home too late, ah?

particle.definition: a filler word used to mark the point between the sentence topic and the rest of the sentence, sometimes replacing a conjunction; emphasizes and calls attention or heed to the sentence topic before continuing
particle.example:
The rain last night was so noisy I couldn't sleep.
→ The rain last night ah, so noisy I couldn't sleep.

particle.definition: used to soften tone, e.g. of a request
particle.example:
Girl, can help me with my phone?
→ Girl ah, can help me with my phone?

The new hire cannot shut up, I tell you. Talking, asking, laughing; really pek chek man.
→ The new hire cannot shut up, I tell you. Talk ah, ask ah, laugh ah; really pek chek man.

interjection.definition: rudely call attention to a present issue; indicate realization of a topic previously discussed to be occurring in the future
interjection.example: Ah! Ah there? You see? @{Orbi good}...

interjection.definition: used to issue a challenge, or impart a challenging tone
expression or exclamation of surprise
ok; acknowledged; used to indicate acknowledgement or approval
interjection.example: Ah, sounds good. We go ahead with your plan ba.

ah@2.etyNotes: Use as an honorific prefix is typically attributed to Min Nan languages (the family including Hokkien, Teochew, Hainanese, Hockchew etc.); use as a prefix of familiarity is common throughout southern Chinese languages.

origin.lit: honorific or diminutive or endearing prefix

affix.definition: honorific prefix to a kinship title
affix.example: Ah Kong and Ah Chek both moved house last year.

affix.definition: prefixed to a name (usually the last syllable) or when addressing an unknown person as a diminutive, or to express familiarity and friendliness.
affix.example:
- Ah Yong is studying Law, at Durham.
- I know he is studying lah, what is he studying?

ar.etyNotes: This is most likely the origin. This use of 合 exists in Hokkien, but not other Chinese languages such as Mandarin; a̍h/ha̍h is the vernacular pronunciation, used for this meaning, while ha̍p is the literary reading and is used for other usual meanings of 合 in Chinese, such as "to join".

verb.definition: curry favour with; get along well with; get into one's good books
verb.example: So if you ar with the IC... you can @{chiah chua} a bit.
verb.exampleSource: 1978, Leong Choon Cheong (quoting Tay Poh Hock). Youth in the Army, p.53

ah balling.etyNotes:
"鴨母" is probably in reference to duck eggs (due to how the dish resembles eggs), which are called 鸭母卵 (ah4 bho2 neng6) or 鸭卵 (ah4 neng6) in Teochew.
鸭母卵 (ah4 bho2 neng6), "mother duck's eggs" is also another possibility for the dish's name, or has at least influenced the alteration of its pronunciation into "ah balling" in Singlish.

origin.lit: ah balling (glutinous rice balls with filling in a sweet soup; tangyuan)

noun.definition: a dish of glutinous rice balls with filling, such as ground peanut or sesame paste mixed with sugar, in a sweet soup; Teochew tangyuan. It is popularly eaten during the Winter Solstice Festival.
noun.example: Tangyuan for the Teochews is known as “Ah Balling”, ... which means “mother duck’s eggs”. The term is used to describe tangyuan’s resemblance to floating duck eggs while being cooked in soup.
noun.exampleSource: 2023, Festive Fever, SCCC. Celebrating Winter Solstice The Singaporean Way. https://festivefever.singaporeccc.org.sg/winter-solstice/archival/2023/winter-solstice-101/

origin.lit: a young Chinese man, stereotypically uncouth, unrefined, and gangsterlike. A stereotypically common male given name.

noun.definition: (derogatory) a young Chinese man, stereotypically uncouth, unrefined, and gangsterlike. The male counterpart of an @{Ah Lian} or @{Ah Huay}. Comes from the stereotypically common male given name 阿明 (a-bêng).
noun.example: The boys are called Ah Bengs and the girls Ah Lians. I have been warned by friends never to make eye contact with them, never to laugh at their ridiculous clothing combinations (white, skin-tight trousers and vest, black belt and a bright yellow handphone stuck to the hip) and never to get into an argument with them because they are usually armed with knives or, wait for it, parangs.
noun.exampleSource: 2001, Neil Humphreys. Notes from an Even Smaller Island, p.83

adjective.definition: having traits associated with an Ah Beng.
adjective.example: And beng or not, their radio ditties are catchier than the flu. ... Boom Boom Boom Boom is a staple in the Beng-mobile phone ringer collection.
adjective.exampleSource: 2000 July 21, Arti Mulchand. The Straits Times (Life!), p.5

origin.lit: a young Chinese man, stereotypically uncouth, unrefined, and gangsterlike. A stereotypically common male given name.

noun.definition: (derogatory) a young Chinese man, stereotypically uncouth, unrefined, and gangsterlike. The male counterpart of an @{Ah Lian} or @{Ah Huay}. Comes from the stereotypically common male given name 阿成 (a-sêng).

adjective.definition: having traits associated with an Ah Seng.

etyLit: a young Chinese man,stereotypically uncouth,unrefined,and gangsterlike
a young Chinese man,stereotypically uncouth,unrefined,and gangsterlike

noun.definition: (derogatory) a posse of uncouth, uneducated delinquents and their ilk.
noun.example: Don't go mix with those Ah Beng Ah Seng over there...

noun.definition: one's father's younger brother
an older, middle-aged man; term of address for a middle-aged man. Male equivalent of an @{Ah Soh}.

ah huay.etyNotes: While 花 (hoe, "flower") is one of the most common characters used to write the stereotypical name, it is not the only possible one. 慧 (hūi / hōe, "bright; intelligent"), 惠 (hūi / hōe, "favour, benevolent, kind"), and several other examples are also common female names which can be rendered as "Huay".

origin.lit: a young Chinese woman, stereotypically uncouth, unrefined, and associated with street gangs; a bimbo. A stereotypically common female given name.

noun.definition: (derogatory) a young Chinese woman, stereotypically uncouth, unrefined, and associated with street gangs; a bimbo. The female counterpart of an @{Ah Beng} or @{Ah Seng}. Comes from the stereotypically common female given name 阿花 (a-hoe).

etyLit: diminutive prefix,or used to express familiarity and friendliness

noun.definition: endearing nickname for someone acting cutesy
grandfather
noun.example: Every Chinese New Year, we gather at Ah Kong's house for a festive reunion dinner.

noun.definition: an elderly man; term of address for an old man. Male equivalent of @{Ah Ma}.
(metaphor, humorous) the government
noun.example: Don't let Ah Kong catch you selling gum.

noun.definition: (metonym, humorous) Lee Kuan Yew, the first Prime Minister of Singapore.
elder brother
noun.example: Ah kor always takes care of us, giving advice and support whenever we need it.

noun.definition: a term of address or endearment for a male person slightly older than oneself
(derogatory) an effeminate man
(derogatory) a male transvestite
(derogatory) a male-to-female transgender person
a male prostitute
an effeminate man
noun.example: Shovelling hard-packed snow is no easy task. It’s a bit like trench-digging during NS, except in the cold and without some sergeant calling you a “gu niang” every few minutes.
noun.exampleSource: 2009 January 11, Colin Goh. The Sunday Times (Lifestyle), p.12

noun.definition: a feminine and ladylike woman

adjective.example: He may be gu niang, but he's also one of the most caring and compassionate individuals I know.
I think the stereotype of girls in the army tending to be more tomboyish is not true... We can be very gu niang (ladylike).
adjective.exampleSource: 2001 March 8, Fiona Chan (quoting Charmaine Chua). The Straits Times (Life! This Weekend), p.8

origin.lit: a young Chinese woman, stereotypically uncouth, unrefined, and associated with street gangs; a bimbo. A stereotypically common female given name.

noun.definition: (derogatory) a young Chinese woman, stereotypically uncouth, unrefined, and associated with street gangs; a bimbo. The female counterpart of an @{Ah Beng} or @{Ah Seng}. Comes from the stereotypically common female given name 阿莲 (a-liân).
noun.example: Often labelled as Bengs and Lians, they howl in Hokkien and gesture in unison while dancing to Euro-trance.
noun.exampleSource: 2001 January 14, Michelle Ho. The Sunday Times (Sunday Plus), p.7

adjective.definition: having traits associated with an Ah Lian.
adjective.example: She is so ah lian, always dressed in chintzy clothes, hanging out at the pool table and smoking with the Ah Bengs, and speaking loudly on her phone wherever she goes.

etyLit: ear cavity; ear hole; ear piercing

noun.definition: a loan shark
noun.example: During those tough times, the coffee shop towkay resorted to borrowing from an ah long to keep his business afloat... but he was soon given many reasons to regret his mistake.

noun.definition: (humorous) Lee Hsien Loong, the third Prime Minister of Singapore. Ah Loong is a homophone of ah long.
grandmother
an elderly woman; term of address for an old woman. Female equivalent of @{Ah Kong}.
noun.example: During peak tourist season, tour groups chock full of ah mas and aunties descend upon the most popular sites across East Asia, each donning sweaters in the most garish of neon shades, and with none of their outfits complete without a wide-brimmed sun hat and hawkish leopard-print-framed sunglasses.

origin.lit: elderly woman; honorific term of address for a woman slightly older than one's mother; father's elder brother's wife

noun.definition: one's father's elder brother's wife
an elderly woman; term of address for an elderly woman.

anneh.usage: While the term itself is not strictly racist, and can be well-meaning or endearing, it is often used in a derogatory and demeaning way by non-Indians to refer to Indians. Thus, flagrant use of the term without understanding is discouraged.
anneh.etyNotes:
The pronunciation "anneh" stems from the informal Tamil pronunciation.

The spelling "ah neh" and its variations are due to conflation with the common diminutive prefix "@{ah}" (Hokkien: 阿, a), as in @{ah beng}, @{ah ma}, etc; it may also have been influenced by (or influenced the development of) the racist and derogatory term @{apu neh neh}.

noun.definition: elder brother; a term of address for an elder brother
a term of address for a man around the same age or slightly older than the speaker, especially one of Tamil or other Indian descent.
(derogatory, racist) an Indian person, especially of Tamil or South Indian descent, or a migrant worker from the Indian subcontinent.
a young and beautiful girl; term of address for a young woman
one's father's elder brother
old man; old uncle; an older middle-aged man

apu neh neh.usage: #{red}#{warn} The term is considered extremely offensive and racist, and should not be used.
apu neh neh.etyNotes: Actual etymology is unknown. Likely a nonsense word based off racist and stereotypical impressions of the sound of the Tamil language; @{anneh} or its Hokkien pronunciation @{ah neh} likely influenced the development of the slur.

origin.lit: elder brother; (derogatory, racist) an Indian person, especially of Tamil or South Indian descent, or a migrant worker from the Indian subcontinent
likely a nonsense word based off racist impressions of the sound of the Tamil language

noun.definition: (derogatory, racist, offensive) a racist slur for an Indian person, especially of Tamil or South Indian descent, or a migrant worker from the Indian subcontinent.
(racist, offensive) a boogeyman
fatty; a fat person. Can be derogatory, neutral, or endearing.
noun.example: The Pokemon Go aunties have endearingly nicknamed Snorlax 'Ah Pui', the Hokkien term for a 'fatty', for its striking similarity to an out-of-shape ah pek.

noun.definition: one's elder brother's wife (sister-in-law)
an older, middle-aged woman; term of address for a middle-aged woman. Female equivalent of an @{Ah Chek}.
noun.example: After the British soldiers left Singapore, she worked as a coffee lady (kopi ah soh) in offices, making drinks and carrying out cleaning chores.

adjective.definition: pertaining to an older, middle-aged woman; having traits such as being wont to complain, gossipy, and old-fashioned.

origin.lit: interjection; particle (see main article for details)
interjection used to ask for elaboration on something said, or point out the obviousness of a statement; usually in a rhetorical or sometimes impolite manner.
etyLit: next to occur; afterward; besides that

interjection.definition: so what?; so?; duh; OK, and?; no shit. A sarcastic or rhetorical rebuttal to an obvious or stupid statement, often dismissive and impolite.
interjection.example:
- I heard that if you want to lose weight, you should eat less.
- Ah then?

origin.lit: (derogatory or endearing) a person from mainland China

noun.definition: (derogatory slur or endearing) a person from mainland China.

ah tong ah seng.etyNotes:
#{dubious} The only source claims that this is of Cantonese origin, but the source is unreliable and uncorroborated. Regardless, the same two names would be transliterated nearly the same way in other Southern Chinese languages (see @{ah seng}).

东 (meaning "east") is very likely the correct character, as it is one of the most common names with the transliteration "Tong", but this is unconfirmed.

origin.lit: a stereotypically common male given name; an uncouth, unrefined young man.

noun.definition: any old body; placeholder names for unspecified ordinary people; Tom, Dick, and Harry
noun.example: In the age of the Internet, every Ah Tong Ah Seng can become a leading expert in any field of knowledge overnight - or so most of them believe, at least.

verb.definition: to want
to need to; must

ai kia stead mai.etyNotes: See also @{kia stead} and @{ai stead mai}.

origin.lit: (interrogative) (do you) want or not want (sth.)?; 愛 (want) + contraction of 毋愛 (not want)

interjection.definition: (dating) do you want to go steady (or not)?
interjection.example: During recess, he mustered up the courage to ask her, "Ai kia stead mai?"

ai pi ai chee.etyNotes: #{likely} One source claims it is of Teochew origin; this is not fully corroborated. Regardless, the phrase also works and is pronounced similarly in related languages like Hokkien (albeit with "pi" corresponding to the character 偏, phiⁿ - which is likely a borrowing from Teochew 便 anyway).

adjective.definition: (lit.) want cheap, want fresh/pretty. Describing a person who always demands the best of both worlds; someone who has unrealistic expectations; someone hard to please.
adjective.example: The food critic was notorious for being ai pi ai chee, rarely giving out positive reviews to the hawker stalls she visited.
synonyms: ai pi ai chee ai tua liap ni
